[[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] has traditionally used the full [[GNOME]] desktop environment; founder [[Mark Shuttleworth]] cited philosophical differences with the GNOME team over the user experience to explain why Ubuntu would use Unity as the default desktop instead of [[GNOME Shell]], beginning April 2011, with

[[List of Ubuntu releases#Ubuntu 11.04 (Natty Narwhal)|Natty Narwhal (11.04)]].<ref name=UbuntuSplits />

[[List of Ubuntu releases#Ubuntu 11.04 (Natty Narwhal)|Ubuntu 11.04 (Natty Narwhal)]].<ref name=UbuntuSplits />
In November 2010, Ubuntu Community Manager [[Jono Bacon]] explained that Ubuntu will continue to ship the GNOME stack, GNOME applications, and optimize Ubuntu for GNOME. The only difference, he wrote, would be that Unity is a different shell for GNOME.<ref>
In November 2010, Ubuntu Community Manager [[Jono Bacon]] explained that Ubuntu will continue to ship the GNOME stack, GNOME applications, and optimize Ubuntu for GNOME. The only difference, he wrote, would be that Unity is a different shell for GNOME.<ref>
